summary.para: Indicates how much any visible DIPs (device independent pixels) overshoot each side of the layout or inline objects.

member.name: DWRITE_OVERHANG_METRICS::left
member.summary: The distance from the left-most visible DIP to its left-alignment edge.

member.name: DWRITE_OVERHANG_METRICS::top
member.summary: The distance from the top-most visible DIP to its top alignment edge.

member.name: DWRITE_OVERHANG_METRICS::right
member.summary: The distance from the right-most visible DIP to its right-alignment edge.

member.name: DWRITE_OVERHANG_METRICS::bottom
member.summary: The distance from the bottom-most visible DIP to its lower-alignment edge.

summary.para: Identifies a string in a font.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_NONE
member.summary: Unspecified font property identifier.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_FULL_NAME
member.summary: The full name of the font, for example "Arial Bold", from name id 4 in the name table.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_WIN32_FAMILY_NAME
member.summary: GDI-compatible family name. Because GDI allows a maximum of four fonts per family, fonts in the same family may have different GDI-compatible family names, for example "Arial", "Arial Narrow", "Arial Black".

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_POSTSCRIPT_NAME
member.summary: The postscript name of the font, for example "GillSans-Bold", from name id 6 in the name table.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_DESIGN_SCRIPT_LANGUAGE_TAG
member.summary: Script/language tag to identify the scripts or languages that the font was primarily designed to support.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_SUPPORTED_SCRIPT_LANGUAGE_TAG
member.summary: Script/language tag to identify the scripts or languages that the font declares it is able to support.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_SEMANTIC_TAG
member.summary: Semantic tag to describe the font, for example Fancy, Decorative, Handmade, Sans-serif, Swiss, Pixel, Futuristic.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_WEIGHT
member.summary: Weight of the font represented as a decimal string in the range 1-999.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_STRETCH
member.summary: Stretch of the font represented as a decimal string in the range 1-9.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_STYLE
member.summary: Style of the font represented as a decimal string in the range 0-2.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_TOTAL
member.summary: Total number of properties.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_PREFERRED_FAMILY_NAME
member.summary: Family name preferred by the designer. This enables font designers to group more than four fonts in a single family without losing compatibility with GDI. This name is typically only present if it differs from the GDI-compatible family name.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_FAMILY_NAME
member.summary: Family name for the weight-width-slope model.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID::DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_FACE_NAME
member.summary: Face name of the font, for example Regular or Bold.

summary.para: Specifies the word wrapping to be used in a particular multiline paragraph.

member.name: DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING::DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING_WRAP
member.summary: Indicates that words are broken across lines to avoid text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING::DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING_NO_WRAP
member.summary: Indicates that words are kept within the same line even when it overflows the layout box. This option is often used with scrolling to reveal overflow text.

member.name: DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING::DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING_EMERGENCY_BREAK
member.summary:
Note Windows 8.1 and later only.
Words are broken across lines to avoid text overflowing the layout box. Emergency wrapping occurs if the word is larger than the maximum width.

member.name: DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING::DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING_WHOLE_WORD
member.summary:
Note Windows 8.1 and later only.
When emergency wrapping, only wrap whole words, never breaking words when the layout width is too small for even a single word.

member.name: DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING::DWRITE_WORD_WRAPPING_CHARACTER
member.summary:
Note Windows 8.1 and later only.
Wrap between any valid character clusters.

summary.para: Defines constants that specify the mechanism by which a font came to be included in a font set.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE::DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE_UNKNOWN
member.summary: Specifies that the font source is unknown, or is not any of the other defined font source types.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE::DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE_PER_MACHINE
member.summary: Specifies that the font source is a font file that's installed for all users on the device.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE::DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE_PER_USER
member.summary: Specifies that the font source is a font file that's installed for the current user.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE::DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE_APPX_PACKAGE
member.summary: Specifies that the font source is an APPX package, which includes one or more font files. The font source name is the full name of the package.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE::DWRITE_FONT_SOURCE_TYPE_REMOTE_FONT_PROVIDER
member.summary: Specifies that the font source is a font provider for downloadable fonts.

summary.para: Represents the internal structure of a device pixel (that is, the physical arrangement of red, green, and blue color components) that is assumed for purposes of rendering text.

member.name: DWRITE_PIXEL_GEOMETRY::DWRITE_PIXEL_GEOMETRY_FLAT
member.summary: The red, green, and blue color components of each pixel are assumed to occupy the same point.

member.name: DWRITE_PIXEL_GEOMETRY::DWRITE_PIXEL_GEOMETRY_RGB
member.summary: Each pixel is composed of three vertical stripes, with red on the left, green in the center, and blue on the right. This is the most common pixel geometry for LCD monitors.

member.name: DWRITE_PIXEL_GEOMETRY::DWRITE_PIXEL_GEOMETRY_BGR
member.summary: Each pixel is composed of three vertical stripes, with blue on the left, green in the center, and red on the right.

summary.para: Defines constants that specify attributes for a font axis.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_ATTRIBUTES::DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_ATTRIBUTES_NONE
member.summary: Specifies no attributes.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_ATTRIBUTES::DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_ATTRIBUTES_VARIABLE
member.summary: Specifies that this axis is implemented as a variation axis in a variable font, with a continuous range of values, such as a range of weights from 100..900. Otherwise, it is either a static axis that holds a single point, or it has a range but doesn't vary, such as optical size in the Skia Heading font (which covers a range of points but doesn't interpolate any new glyph outlines).

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_ATTRIBUTES::DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_ATTRIBUTES_HIDDEN
member.summary: Specifies that this axis is recommended to be remain hidden in user interfaces. The font developer may recommend this if an axis is intended to be accessed only programmatically, or is meant for font-internal or font-developer use only. The axis may be exposed in lower-level font inspection utilities, but should not be exposed in common nor even advanced-mode user interfaces in content-authoring apps.

summary.para: Specifies the type of DirectWrite factory object.

member.name: DWRITE_FACTORY_TYPE::DWRITE_FACTORY_TYPE_SHARED
member.summary: Indicates that the DirectWrite factory is a shared factory and that it allows for the reuse of cached font data across multiple in-process components. Such factories also take advantage of cross process font caching components for better performance.

member.name: DWRITE_FACTORY_TYPE::DWRITE_FACTORY_TYPE_ISOLATED
member.summary: Indicates that the DirectWrite factory object is isolated. Objects created from the isolated factory do not interact with internal DirectWrite state from other components.

summary.para: Defines constants that specify how font families are grouped together.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FAMILY_MODEL::DWRITE_FONT_FAMILY_MODEL_TYPOGRAPHIC
member.summary: Families are grouped by the typographic family name preferred by the font author. The family can contain as many faces as the font author wants. This corresponds to DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_TYPOGRAPHIC_FAMILY_NAME.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FAMILY_MODEL::DWRITE_FONT_FAMILY_MODEL_WEIGHT_STRETCH_STYLE
member.summary: Families are grouped by the weight-stretch-style family name, where all faces that differ only by those three axes are grouped into the same family, but any other axes go into a distinct family. For example, the Sitka family with six different optical sizes yields six separate families (Sitka Caption, Display, Text, Subheading, Heading, Banner...). This corresponds to DWRITE_FONT_PROPERTY_ID_WEIGHT_STRETCH_STYLE_FAMILY_NAME.

summary.para: Indicates the measuring method used for text layout.

member.name: DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE::DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE_NATURAL
member.summary: Specifies that text is measured using glyph ideal metrics whose values are independent to the current display resolution.

member.name: DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE::DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE_GDI_CLASSIC
member.summary: Specifies that text is measured using glyph display-compatible metrics whose values tuned for the current display resolution.

member.name: DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE::DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE_GDI_NATURAL
member.summary: Specifies that text is measured using the same glyph display metrics as text measured by GDI using a font created with CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY.

summary.para: The DWRITE_CARET_METRICS structure specifies the metrics for caret placement in a font.

member.name: DWRITE_CARET_METRICS::slopeRise
member.summary: Vertical rise of the caret in font design units. Rise / Run yields the caret angle. Rise = 1 for perfectly upright fonts (non-italic).

member.name: DWRITE_CARET_METRICS::slopeRun
member.summary: Horizontal run of the caret in font design units. Rise / Run yields the caret angle. Run = 0 for perfectly upright fonts (non-italic).

member.name: DWRITE_CARET_METRICS::offset
member.summary: Horizontal offset of the caret, in font design units, along the baseline for good appearance. Offset = 0 for perfectly upright fonts (non-italic).

summary.para: Contains information regarding the size and placement of strikethroughs.

member.name: DWRITE_STRIKETHROUGH::width
member.summary: A value that indicates the width of the strikethrough, measured parallel to the baseline.

member.name: DWRITE_STRIKETHROUGH::thickness
member.summary: A value that indicates the thickness of the strikethrough, measured perpendicular to the baseline.

member.name: DWRITE_STRIKETHROUGH::offset
member.summary: A value that indicates the offset of the strikethrough from the baseline. A positive offset represents a position below the baseline and a negative offset is above. Typically, the offset will be negative.

member.name: DWRITE_STRIKETHROUGH::readingDirection
member.summary: Reading direction of the text associated with the strikethrough. This value is used to interpret whether the width value runs horizontally or vertically.

member.name: DWRITE_STRIKETHROUGH::flowDirection
member.summary: Flow direction of the text associated with the strikethrough. This value is used to interpret whether the thickness value advances top to bottom, left to right, or right to left.

member.name: DWRITE_STRIKETHROUGH::localeName
member.summary: An array of characters containing the locale of the text that is the strikethrough is being drawn over.

member.name: DWRITE_STRIKETHROUGH::measuringMode
member.summary: The measuring mode can be useful to the renderer to determine how underlines are rendered, such as rounding the thickness to a whole pixel in GDI-compatible modes.

summary.para: Contains the metrics associated with text after layout.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::left
member.summary: A value that indicates the left-most point of formatted text relative to the layout box, while excluding any glyph overhang.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::top
member.summary: A value that indicates the top-most point of formatted text relative to the layout box, while excluding any glyph overhang.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::width
member.summary: A value that indicates the width of the formatted text, while ignoring trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::widthIncludingTrailingWhitespace
member.summary: The width of the formatted text, taking into account the trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::height
member.summary: The height of the formatted text. The height of an empty string is set to the same value as that of the default font.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::layoutWidth
member.summary: The initial width given to the layout. It can be either larger or smaller than the text content width, depending on whether the text was wrapped.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::layoutHeight
member.summary: Initial height given to the layout. Depending on the length of the text, it may be larger or smaller than the text content height.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::maxBidiReorderingDepth
member.summary: The maximum reordering count of any line of text, used to calculate the most number of hit-testing boxes needed. If the layout has no bidirectional text, or no text at all, the minimum level is 1.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_METRICS::lineCount
member.summary: Total number of lines.

summary.para: The DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES structure specifies script properties for caret navigation and justification.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::isoScriptCode
member.summary:
The standardized four character code for the given script.
Note These only include the general Unicode scripts, not any additional ISO 15924 scripts for bibliographic distinction.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::isoScriptNumber
member.summary: The standardized numeric code, ranging 0-999.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::clusterLookahead
member.summary:
Number of characters to estimate look-ahead for complex scripts. Latin and all Kana are generally 1. Indic scripts are up to 15, and most others are 8.
Note Combining marks and variation selectors can produce clusters that are longer than these look-aheads, so this estimate is considered typical language use. Diacritics must be tested explicitly separately.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::justificationCharacter
member.summary:
Appropriate character to elongate the given script for justification. For example:
Arabic - U+0640 Tatweel
Ogham - U+1680 Ogham Space Mark

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::restrictCaretToClusters
member.summary: Restrict the caret to whole clusters, like Thai and Devanagari. Scripts such as Arabic by default allow navigation between clusters. Others like Thai always navigate across whole clusters.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::usesWordDividers
member.summary: The language uses dividers between words, such as spaces between Latin or the Ethiopic wordspace. Examples include Latin, Greek, Devanagari, and Ethiopic. Chinese, Korean, and Thai are excluded.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::isDiscreteWriting
member.summary: The characters are discrete units from each other. This includes both block scripts and clustered scripts. Examples include Latin, Greek, Cyrillic, Hebrew, Chinese, and Thai.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::isBlockWriting
member.summary: The language is a block script, expanding between characters. Examples include Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Bopomofo.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::isDistributedWithinCluster
member.summary: The language is justified within glyph clusters, not just between glyph clusters, such as the character sequence of Thai Lu and Sara Am (U+E026, U+E033), which form a single cluster but still expand between them. Examples include Thai, Lao, and Khmer.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::isConnectedWriting
member.summary:
The script's clusters are connected to each other (such as the baseline-linked Devanagari), and no separation is added between characters.
Note Cursively linked scripts like Arabic are also connected (but not all connected scripts are cursive).
Examples include Devanagari, Arabic, Syriac, Bengala, Gurmukhi, and Ogham. Latin, Chinese, and Thaana are excluded.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::isCursiveWriting
member.summary:
The script is naturally cursive (Arabic and Syriac), meaning it uses other justification methods like kashida extension rather than inter-character spacing.
Note Although other scripts like Latin and Japanese might actually support handwritten cursive forms, they are not considered cursive scripts.
Examples include Arabic, Syriac, and Mongolian. Thaana, Devanagari, Latin, and Chinese are excluded.

member.name: DWRITE_SCRIPT_PROPERTIES::reserved
member.summary: Reserved

summary.para: Contains information about the width, thickness, offset, run height, reading direction, and flow direction of an underline.

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::width
member.summary: A value that indicates the width of the underline, measured parallel to the baseline.

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::thickness
member.summary: A value that indicates the thickness of the underline, measured perpendicular to the baseline.

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::offset
member.summary: A value that indicates the offset of the underline from the baseline. A positive offset represents a position below the baseline (away from the text) and a negative offset is above (toward the text).

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::runHeight
member.summary: A value that indicates the height of the tallest run where the underline is applied.

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::readingDirection
member.summary: A value that indicates the reading direction of the text associated with the underline. This value is used to interpret whether the width value runs horizontally or vertically.

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::flowDirection
member.summary: A value that indicates the flow direction of the text associated with the underline. This value is used to interpret whether the thickness value advances top to bottom, left to right, or right to left.

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::localeName
member.summary: An array of characters which contains the locale of the text that the underline is being drawn under. For example, in vertical text, the underline belongs on the left for Chinese but on the right for Japanese.

member.name: DWRITE_UNDERLINE::measuringMode
member.summary: The measuring mode can be useful to the renderer to determine how underlines are rendered, such as rounding the thickness to a whole pixel in GDI-compatible modes.

member.name: DWRITE_OPTICAL_ALIGNMENT::DWRITE_OPTICAL_ALIGNMENT_NONE
member.summary: Align to the default origin and side-bearings of the glyph.

member.name: DWRITE_OPTICAL_ALIGNMENT::DWRITE_OPTICAL_ALIGNMENT_NO_SIDE_BEARINGS
member.summary: Align to the ink of the glyphs, such that the black box abuts the margins.

summary.para: The DWRITE_VERTICAL_GLYPH_ORIENTATION enumeration contains values that specify the desired kind of glyph orientation for the text.

member.name: DWRITE_VERTICAL_GLYPH_ORIENTATION::DWRITE_VERTICAL_GLYPH_ORIENTATION_DEFAULT
member.summary: The default glyph orientation. In vertical layout, naturally horizontal scripts (Latin, Thai, Arabic, Devanagari) rotate 90 degrees clockwise, while ideographic scripts (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) remain upright, 0 degrees.

member.name: DWRITE_VERTICAL_GLYPH_ORIENTATION::DWRITE_VERTICAL_GLYPH_ORIENTATION_STACKED
member.summary: Stacked glyph orientation. Ideographic scripts and scripts that permit stacking (Latin, Hebrew) are stacked in vertical reading layout. Connected scripts (Arabic, Syriac, 'Phags-pa, Ogham), which would otherwise look broken if glyphs were kept at 0 degrees, remain connected and rotate.

member.name: DWRITE_HIT_TEST_METRICS::isTrimmed

summary.para: The optional adjustment to a glyph's position.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_OFFSET::advanceOffset
member.summary: The offset in the advance direction of the run. A positive advance offset moves the glyph to the right (in pre-transform coordinates) if the run is left-to-right or to the left if the run is right-to-left.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_OFFSET::ascenderOffset
member.summary: The offset in the ascent direction, that is, the direction ascenders point. A positive ascender offset moves the glyph up (in pre-transform coordinates). A negative ascender offset moves the glyph down.

member.name: DWRITE_SHAPING_TEXT_PROPERTIES::isShapedAlone
member.summary: Indicates that the glyph is shaped alone.

member.name: DWRITE_SHAPING_TEXT_PROPERTIES::reserved
member.summary: Reserved for future use.

summary.para: The DWRITE_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE enumeration contains values that specify the type of antialiasing to use for text when the rendering mode calls for antialiasing.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE::DWRITE_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE_CLEARTYPE
member.summary: ClearType antialiasing computes coverage independently for the red, green, and blue color elements of each pixel. This allows for more detail than conventional antialiasing. However, because there is no one alpha value for each pixel, ClearType is not suitable for rendering text onto a transparent intermediate bitmap.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE::DWRITE_TEXT_ANTIALIAS_MODE_GRAYSCALE
member.summary:
Grayscale antialiasing computes one coverage value for each pixel. Because the alpha value of each pixel is well-defined, text can be rendered onto a transparent bitmap, which can then be composited with other content.
Note Grayscale rendering with IDWriteBitmapRenderTarget1 uses premultiplied alpha.

summary.para: The DWRITE_PANOSE_SPACING enumeration contains values that specify character spacing (monospace versus proportional).

member.name: DWRITE_PANOSE_SPACING::DWRITE_PANOSE_SPACING_ANY

member.summary: No fit for spacing.

summary.para: The informational string enumeration which identifies a string embedded in a font file.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_NONE
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the unspecified name ID.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_COPYRIGHT_NOTICE
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the copyright notice provided by the font.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_VERSION_STRINGS
member.summary: Indicates the string containing a version number.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_TRADEMARK
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the trademark information provided by the font.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_MANUFACTURER
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the name of the font manufacturer.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_DESIGNER
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the name of the font designer.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_DESIGNER_URL
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the URL of the font designer (with protocol, e.g., http://, ftp://).

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_DESCRIPTION
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the description of the font. This may also contain revision information, usage recommendations, history, features, and so on.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_FONT_VENDOR_URL
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the URL of the font vendor (with protocol, e.g., http://, ftp://). If a unique serial number is embedded in the URL, it can be used to register the font.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_LICENSE_DESCRIPTION
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the description of how the font may be legally used, or different example scenarios for licensed use.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_LICENSE_INFO_URL
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the URL where additional licensing information can be found.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_WIN32_FAMILY_NAMES
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the GDI-compatible family name. Since GDI allows a maximum of four fonts per family, fonts in the same family may have different GDI-compatible family names (e.g., "Arial", "Arial Narrow", "Arial Black").

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_WIN32_SUBFAMILY_NAMES
member.summary: Indicates the string containing a GDI-compatible subfamily name.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_SAMPLE_TEXT
member.summary:
Contains sample text for display in font lists. This can be the font name or any other text that the designer thinks is the best
example to display the font in.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_FULL_NAME
member.summary: The full name of the font, like Arial Bold, from name id 4 in the name table

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_POSTSCRIPT_NAME
member.summary: The postscript name of the font, like GillSans-Bold, from name id 6 in the name table.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_POSTSCRIPT_CID_NAME
member.summary: The postscript CID findfont name, from name id 20 in the name table

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_PREFERRED_FAMILY_NAMES
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the family name preferred by the designer. This enables font designers to group more than four fonts in a single family without losing compatibility with GDI. This name is typically only present if it differs from the GDI-compatible family name.

member.name: DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_ID::DWRITE_INFORMATIONAL_STRING_PREFERRED_SUBFAMILY_NAMES
member.summary: Indicates the string containing the subfamily name preferred by the designer. This name is typically only present if it differs from the GDI-compatible subfamily name.

summary.para: The DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY structure specifies justification info per glyph.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::expansionMinimum
member.summary: Minimum amount of expansion to apply to the side of the glyph. This might vary from zero to infinity, typically being zero except for kashida.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::expansionMaximum
member.summary: Maximum amount of expansion to apply to the side of the glyph. This might vary from zero to infinity, being zero for fixed-size characters and connected scripts, and non-zero for discrete scripts, and non-zero for cursive scripts at expansion points.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::compressionMaximum
member.summary: Maximum amount of compression to apply to the side of the glyph. This might vary from zero up to the glyph cluster size.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::expansionPriority
member.summary: Priority of this expansion point. Larger priorities are applied later, while priority zero does nothing.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::compressionPriority
member.summary: Priority of this compression point. Larger priorities are applied later, while priority zero does nothing.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::allowResidualExpansion
member.summary: Allow this expansion point to use up any remaining slack space even after all expansion priorities have been used up.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::allowResidualCompression
member.summary: Allow this compression point to use up any remaining space even after all compression priorities have been used up.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::applyToLeadingEdge
member.summary: Apply expansion and compression to the leading edge of the glyph. This bit is FALSE (0) for connected scripts, fixed-size characters, and diacritics. It is generally FALSE within a multi-glyph cluster, unless the script allows expansion of glyphs within a cluster, like Thai.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::applyToTrailingEdge
member.summary: Apply expansion and compression to the trailing edge of the glyph. This bit is FALSE (0) for connected scripts, fixed-size characters, and diacritics. It is generally FALSE within a multi-glyph cluster, unless the script allows expansion of glyphs within a cluster, like Thai.

member.name: DWRITE_JUSTIFICATION_OPPORTUNITY::reserved
member.summary: Reserved

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_BREAKPOINT::isSoftHyphen

summary.para: Contains the information needed by renderers to draw glyph runs.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::fontFace
member.summary: The physical font face object to draw with.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::fontEmSize
member.summary: The logical size of the font in DIPs (equals 1/96 inch), not points.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::glyphCount
member.summary: The number of glyphs in the glyph run.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::glyphIndices
member.summary: A pointer to an array of indices to render for the glyph run.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::glyphAdvances
member.summary: A pointer to an array containing glyph advance widths for the glyph run.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::glyphOffsets
member.summary: A pointer to an array containing glyph offsets for the glyph run.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::isSideways
member.summary: If true, specifies that glyphs are rotated 90 degrees to the left and vertical metrics are used. Vertical writing is achieved by specifying isSideways = true and rotating the entire run 90 degrees to the right via a rotate transform.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_RUN::bidiLevel
member.summary: The implicit resolved bidi level of the run. Odd levels indicate right-to-left languages like Hebrew and Arabic, while even levels indicate left-to-right languages like English and Japanese (when written horizontally). For right-to-left languages, the text origin is on the right, and text should be drawn to the left.

member.summary: The height of the inline object.

member.name: DWRITE_INLINE_OBJECT_METRICS::baseline
member.summary: The distance from the top of the object to the point where it is lined up with the adjacent text. If the baseline is at the bottom, then baseline simply equals height.

member.name: DWRITE_INLINE_OBJECT_METRICS::supportsSideways
member.summary: A Boolean flag that indicates whether the object is to be placed upright or alongside the text baseline for vertical text.

summary.para: The method used for line spacing in a text layout.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING_METHOD::DWRITE_LINE_SPACING_METHOD_DEFAULT
member.summary: Line spacing depends solely on the content, adjusting to accommodate the size of fonts and inline objects.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING_METHOD::DWRITE_LINE_SPACING_METHOD_UNIFORM
member.summary: Lines are explicitly set to uniform spacing, regardless of the size of fonts and inline objects. This can be useful to avoid the uneven appearance that can occur from font fallback.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING_METHOD::DWRITE_LINE_SPACING_METHOD_PROPORTIONAL
member.summary:
Line spacing and baseline distances are proportional to the computed values based on the content, the size of the fonts and inline objects.
Note This value is only available on Windows 10 or later and it can be used with IDWriteTextLayout3::SetLineSpacing, but can not be used with IDWriteTextFormat::SetLineSpacing.

summary.para: Specifies the location of a resource.

member.name: DWRITE_LOCALITY::DWRITE_LOCALITY_REMOTE
member.summary: The resource is remote, and information about it is unknown, including the file size and date. If you attempt to create a font or file stream, the creation will fail until locality becomes at least partial.

member.name: DWRITE_LOCALITY::DWRITE_LOCALITY_PARTIAL
member.summary: The resource is partially local, which means you can query the size and date of the file stream. With this type, you also might be able to create a font face and retrieve the particular glyphs for metrics and drawing, but not all the glyphs will be present.

member.name: DWRITE_LOCALITY::DWRITE_LOCALITY_LOCAL
member.summary: The resource is completely local, and all font functions can be called without concern of missing data or errors related to network connectivity.

summary.para: Indicates the condition at the edges of inline object or text used to determine line-breaking behavior.

member.name: DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION::DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION_NEUTRAL
member.summary: Indicates whether a break is allowed by determining the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION::DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION_CAN_BREAK
member.summary: Indicates that a line break is allowed, unless overruled by the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object, either prohibited by a "may not break" condition or forced by a "must break" condition.

member.name: DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION::DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION_MAY_NOT_BREAK
member.summary: Indicates that there should be no line break, unless overruled by a "must break" condition from the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION::DWRITE_BREAK_CONDITION_MUST_BREAK
member.summary: Indicates that the line break must happen, regardless of the condition of the adjacent text span or inline object.

member.name: DWRITE_COLOR_GLYPH_RUN::runColor
member.summary: Color value of the run; if all members are zero, the run should be drawn using the current brush.

member.name: DWRITE_COLOR_GLYPH_RUN::paletteIndex

summary.para: Represents a method of rendering glyphs.

member.name: DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE::DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_DEFAULT
member.summary: Specifies that the rendering mode is determined automatically, based on the font and size.

member.name: DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE::DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_ALIASED
member.summary: Specifies that no anti-aliasing is performed. Each pixel is either set to the foreground color of the text or retains the color of the background.

member.name: DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE::DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_GDI_CLASSIC
member.summary: Specifies that antialiasing is performed in the horizontal direction and the appearance of glyphs is layout-compatible with GDI using CLEARTYPE_QUALITY. Use DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE_GDI_CLASSIC to get glyph advances. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE::DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_GDI_NATURAL
member.summary: Specifies that antialiasing is performed in the horizontal direction and the appearance of glyphs is layout-compatible with GDI using CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY. Glyph advances are close to the font design advances, but are still rounded to whole pixels. Use DWRITE_MEASURING_MODE_GDI_NATURAL to get glyph advances. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE::DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_NATURAL
member.summary: Specifies that antialiasing is performed in the horizontal direction. This rendering mode allows glyphs to be positioned with subpixel precision and is therefore suitable for natural (i.e., resolution-independent) layout. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE::DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_NATURAL_SYMMETRIC
member.summary: Similar to natural mode except that antialiasing is performed in both the horizontal and vertical directions. This is typically used at larger sizes to make curves and diagonal lines look smoother. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE::DWRITE_RENDERING_MODE_OUTLINE
member.summary: Specifies that rendering should bypass the rasterizer and use the outlines directly. This is typically used at very large sizes.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_RANGE::startPosition
member.summary: The start position of the text range.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXT_RANGE::length
member.summary: The number positions in the text range.

summary.para: Specifies properties used to identify and execute typographic features in the current font face.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE::nameTag
member.summary: The feature OpenType name identifier.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE::parameter
member.summary: The execution parameter of the feature.

summary.para: Specifies algorithmic style simulations to be applied to the font face. Bold and oblique simulations can be combined via bitwise OR operation.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS::DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS_NONE
member.summary: Indicates that no simulations are applied to the font face.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS::DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS_BOLD
member.summary: Indicates that algorithmic emboldening is applied to the font face. DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS_BOLD increases weight by applying a widening algorithm to the glyph outline. This may be used to simulate a bold weight where no designed bold weight is available.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS::DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS_OBLIQUE
member.summary: Indicates that algorithmic italicization is applied to the font face. DWRITE_FONT_SIMULATIONS_OBLIQUE applies obliquing (shear) to the glyph outline. This may be used to simulate an oblique/italic style where no designed oblique/italic style is available.

summary.para: Specifies how to apply number substitution on digits and related punctuation.

member.name: DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD::DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD_FROM_CULTURE
member.summary: Specifies that the substitution method should be determined based on the LOCALE_IDIGITSUBSTITUTION value of the specified text culture.

member.name: DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD::DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD_CONTEXTUAL
member.summary: If the culture is Arabic or Persian, specifies that the number shapes depend on the context. Either traditional or nominal number shapes are used, depending on the nearest preceding strong character or (if there is none) the reading direction of the paragraph.

member.name: DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD::DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD_NONE
member.summary: Specifies that code points 0x30-0x39 are always rendered as nominal numeral shapes (ones of the European number), that is, no substitution is performed.

member.name: DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD::DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD_NATIONAL
member.summary: Specifies that numbers are rendered using the national number shapes as specified by the LOCALE_SNATIVEDIGITS value of the specified text culture.

member.name: DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD::DWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD_TRADITIONAL
member.summary: Specifies that numbers are rendered using the traditional shapes for the specified culture. For most cultures, this is the same as NativeNational. However, NativeNational results in Latin numbers for some Arabic cultures, whereasDWRITE_NUMBER_SUBSTITUTION_METHOD_TRADITIONAL results in arabic numbers for all Arabic cultures.

summary.para: Sets the vertical spacing between lines of text.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING::method
member.summary: Method used to determine line spacing.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING::height
member.summary:
Spacing between lines. The interpretation of this parameter depends upon the line spacing method, as follows:
Line spacing: ignored
uniform line spacing: explicit distance in DIPs between lines
proportional line spacing: a scaling factor to be applied to the computed line height; for each line, the height of the line is computed as for default line spacing, and the scaling factor is applied to that value.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING::baseline
member.summary:
Distance from top of line to baseline. The interpretation of this parameter depends upon the line spacing method, as follows:
default line spacing: ignored
uniform line spacing: explicit distance in DIPs from the top of the line to the baseline
proportional line spacing: a scaling factor applied to the computed baseline; for each line, the baseline distance is computed as for default line spacing, and the scaling factor is applied to that value.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING::leadingBefore
member.summary: Proportion of the entire leading distributed before the line. The allowed value is between 0 and 1.0. The remaining leading is distributed after the line. It is ignored for the default and uniform line spacing methods. The leading that is available to distribute before or after the line depends on the values of the height and baseline parameters.

member.name: DWRITE_LINE_SPACING::fontLineGapUsage
member.summary: Specify whether DWRITE_FONT_METRICS::lineGap value should be part of the line metrics.

member.name: DWRITE_FLOW_DIRECTION::DWRITE_FLOW_DIRECTION_RIGHT_TO_LEFT

member.summary: Choose grid fitting based on the font's table information.

member.summary: Always disable grid fitting, using the ideal glyph outlines.

member.summary: Enable grid fitting, adjusting glyph outlines for device pixel display.

summary.para: Specifies the trimming option for text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: DWRITE_TRIMMING::granularity
member.summary: A value that specifies the text granularity used to trim text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: DWRITE_TRIMMING::delimiter
member.summary: A character code used as the delimiter that signals the beginning of the portion of text to be preserved. Text starting from the Nth occurence of the delimiter (where N equals delimiterCount) counting backwards from the end of the text block will be preserved. For example, given the text is a path like c:\A\B\C\D\file.txt and delimiter equal to '\' and delimiterCount equal to 1, the file.txt portion of the text would be preserved. Specifying a delimiterCount of 2 would preserve D\file.txt.

member.name: DWRITE_TRIMMING::delimiterCount
member.summary: The delimiter count, counting from the end of the text, to preserve text from.

summary.para: Specifies the container format of a font resource. A container format is distinct from a font file format (DWRITE_FONT_FILE_TYPE) because the container describes the container in which the underlying font file is packaged.
Identifies a type of alpha texture.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXTURE_TYPE::DWRITE_TEXTURE_ALIASED_1x1
member.summary: Specifies an alpha texture for aliased text rendering (that is, each pixel is either fully opaque or fully transparent), with one byte per pixel.

member.name: DWRITE_TEXTURE_TYPE::DWRITE_TEXTURE_CLEARTYPE_3x1
member.summary: Specifies an alpha texture for ClearType text rendering, with three bytes per pixel in the horizontal dimension and one byte per pixel in the vertical dimension.

summary.para: Specifies the metrics of an individual glyph.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_METRICS::leftSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the glyph origin to the left edge of the black box. The glyph origin is the current horizontal writing position. A negative value means the black box extends to the left of the origin (often true for lowercase italic 'f').

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_METRICS::advanceWidth
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the origin of the current glyph to the origin of the next glyph when writing horizontally.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_METRICS::rightSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the X offset from the right edge of the black box to the origin of the next glyph when writing horizontally. The value is negative when the right edge of the black box overhangs the layout box.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_METRICS::topSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the vertical offset from the vertical origin to the top of the black box. Thus, a positive value adds whitespace whereas a negative value means the glyph overhangs the top of the layout box.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_METRICS::advanceHeight
member.summary: Specifies the Y offset from the vertical origin of the current glyph to the vertical origin of the next glyph when writing vertically. Note that the term "origin" by itself denotes the horizontal origin. The vertical origin is different. Its Y coordinate is specified by verticalOriginY value, and its X coordinate is half the advanceWidth to the right of the horizontal origin.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_METRICS::bottomSideBearing
member.summary: Specifies the vertical distance from the bottom edge of the black box to the advance height. This is positive when the bottom edge of the black box is within the layout box, or negative when the bottom edge of black box overhangs the layout box.

member.name: DWRITE_GLYPH_METRICS::verticalOriginY
member.summary: Specifies the Y coordinate of a glyph's vertical origin, in the font's design coordinate system. The y coordinate of a glyph's vertical origin is the sum of the glyph's top side bearing and the top (that is, yMax) of the glyph's bounding box.

summary.para: Represents a value for a font axis. Used when querying and creating font instances.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_VALUE::axisTag
member.summary: The four-character identifier of the font axis (for example, weight, width, slant, italic, and so on).

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_AXIS_VALUE::value
member.summary:
A value for the axis specified in axisTag. The meaning and range of the value depends on the semantics of the particular axis. Certain well-known axes have standard ranges and defaults. Here are some examples.
- Weight (1..1000, default == 400) - Width (>0, default == 100) - Slant (-90..90, default == -20) - Italic (0 or 1)

member.summary: An array of indices to the glyph indices array, of the first glyphs of all the glyph clusters of the glyphs to render.

member.summary: Corresponding text position in the string this glyph run came from. This is relative to the beginning of the string represented by the IDWriteTextLayout object.

summary.para: A value that indicates the typographic feature of text supplied by the font.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_ALTERNATIVE_FRACTIONS
member.summary:
Replaces figures separated by a slash with an alternative form.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'afrc'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_PETITE_CAPITALS_FROM_CAPITALS
member.summary:
Turns capital characters into petite capitals. It is generally used for words which would otherwise be set in all caps, such as acronyms, but which are desired in petite-cap form to avoid disrupting the flow of text. See the pcap feature description for notes on the relationship of caps, smallcaps and petite caps.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'c2pc'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_SMALL_CAPITALS_FROM_CAPITALS
member.summary:
Turns capital characters into small capitals. It is generally used for words which would otherwise be set in all caps, such as acronyms, but which are desired in small-cap form to avoid disrupting the flow of text.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'c2sc'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_CONTEXTUAL_ALTERNATES
member.summary:
In specified situations, replaces default glyphs with alternate forms which provide better joining behavior. Used in script typefaces which are designed to have some or all of their glyphs join.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'calt'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_CASE_SENSITIVE_FORMS
member.summary:
Shifts various punctuation marks up to a position that works better with all-capital sequences or sets of lining figures; also changes oldstyle figures to lining figures. By default, glyphs in a text face are designed to work with lowercase characters. Some characters should be shifted vertically to fit the higher visual center of all-capital or lining text. Also, lining figures are the same height (or close to it) as capitals, and fit much better with all-capital text.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'case'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_GLYPH_COMPOSITION_DECOMPOSITION
member.summary:
To minimize the number of glyph alternates, it is sometimes desired to decompose a character into two glyphs. Additionally, it may be preferable to compose two characters into a single glyph for better glyph processing. This feature permits such composition/decomposition. The feature should be processed as the first feature processed, and should be processed only when it is called.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ccmp'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_CONTEXTUAL_LIGATURES
member.summary:
Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. Unlike other ligature features, clig specifies the context in which the ligature is recommended. This capability is important in some script designs and for swash ligatures.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'clig'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_CAPITAL_SPACING
member.summary:
Globally adjusts inter-glyph spacing for all-capital text. Most typefaces contain capitals and lowercase characters, and the capitals are positioned to work with the lowercase. When capitals are used for words, they need more space between them for legibility and esthetics. This feature would not apply to monospaced designs. Of course the user may want to override this behavior in order to do more pronounced letterspacing for esthetic reasons.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'cpsp'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_CONTEXTUAL_SWASH
member.summary:
Replaces default character glyphs with corresponding swash glyphs in a specified context. Note that there may be more than one swash alternate for a given character.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'cswh'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_CURSIVE_POSITIONING
member.summary:
In cursive scripts like Arabic, this feature cursively positions adjacent glyphs.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'curs'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_DEFAULT
member.summary: The default.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_DISCRETIONARY_LIGATURES
member.summary:
Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. This feature covers those ligatures which may be used for special effect, at the user's preference.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'dlig'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_EXPERT_FORMS
member.summary:
Replaces standard forms in Japanese fonts with corresponding forms preferred by typographers. For example, a user would invoke this feature to replace kanji character U+5516 with U+555E.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'expt'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_FRACTIONS
member.summary:
Replaces figures separated by a slash with 'common' (diagonal) fractions.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'frac'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_FULL_WIDTH
member.summary:
Replaces glyphs set on other widths with glyphs set on full (usually em) widths. In a CJKV font, this may include "lower ASCII" Latin characters and various symbols. In a European font, this feature replaces proportionally-spaced glyphs with monospaced glyphs, which are generally set on widths of 0.6 em. For example, a user may invoke this feature in a Japanese font to get full monospaced Latin glyphs instead of the corresponding proportionally-spaced versions.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'fwid'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_HALF_FORMS
member.summary:
Produces the half forms of consonants in Indic scripts. For example, in Hindi (Devanagari script), the conjunct KKa, obtained by doubling the Ka, is denoted with a half form of Ka followed by the full form.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'half'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_HALANT_FORMS
member.summary:
Produces the halant forms of consonants in Indic scripts. For example, in Sanskrit (Devanagari script), syllable final consonants are frequently required in their halant form.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'haln'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_ALTERNATE_HALF_WIDTH
member.summary:
Respaces glyphs designed to be set on full-em widths, fitting them onto half-em widths. This differs from hwid in that it does not substitute new glyphs.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'halt'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_HISTORICAL_FORMS
member.summary:
Replaces the default (current) forms with the historical alternates. While some ligatures are also used for historical effect, this feature deals only with single characters. Some fonts include the historical forms as alternates, so they can be used for a 'period' effect.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hist'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_HORIZONTAL_KANA_ALTERNATES
member.summary:
Replaces standard kana with forms that have been specially designed for only horizontal writing. This is a typographic optimization for improved fit and more even color.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hkna'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_HISTORICAL_LIGATURES
member.summary:
Replaces the default (current) forms with the historical alternates. Some ligatures were in common use in the past, but appear anachronistic today. Some fonts include the historical forms as alternates, so they can be used for a 'period' effect.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hlig'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_HALF_WIDTH
member.summary:
Replaces glyphs on proportional widths, or fixed widths other than half an em, with glyphs on half-em (en) widths. Many CJKV fonts have glyphs which are set on multiple widths; this feature selects the half-em version. There are various contexts in which this is the preferred behavior, including compatibility with older desktop documents.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hwid'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_HOJO_KANJI_FORMS
member.summary:
Used to access the JIS X 0212-1990 glyphs for the cases when the JIS X 0213:2004 form is encoded. The JIS X 0212-1990 (aka, "Hojo Kanji") and JIS X 0213:2004 character sets overlap significantly. In some cases their prototypical glyphs differ. When building fonts that support both JIS X 0212-1990 and JIS X 0213:2004 (such as those supporting the Adobe-Japan 1-6 character collection), it is recommended that JIS X 0213:2004 forms be the preferred encoded form.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'hojo'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_JIS04_FORMS
member.summary:
The National Language Council (NLC) of Japan has defined new glyph shapes for a number of JIS characters, which were incorporated into JIS X 0213:2004 as new prototypical forms. The 'jp04' feature is A subset of the 'nlck' feature, and is used to access these prototypical glyphs in a manner that maintains the integrity of JIS X 0213:2004.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp04'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_JIS78_FORMS
member.summary:
Replaces default (JIS90) Japanese glyphs with the corresponding forms from the JIS C 6226-1978 (JIS78) specification.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp78'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_JIS83_FORMS
member.summary:
Replaces default (JIS90) Japanese glyphs with the corresponding forms from the JIS X 0208-1983 (JIS83) specification.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp83'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_JIS90_FORMS
member.summary:
Replaces Japanese glyphs from the JIS78 or JIS83 specifications with the corresponding forms from the JIS X 0208-1990 (JIS90) specification.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'jp90'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_KERNING
member.summary:
Adjusts amount of space between glyphs, generally to provide optically consistent spacing between glyphs. Although a well-designed typeface has consistent inter-glyph spacing overall, some glyph combinations require adjustment for improved legibility. Besides standard adjustment in the horizontal direction, this feature can supply size-dependent kerning data via device tables, "cross-stream" kerning in the Y text direction, and adjustment of glyph placement independent of the advance adjustment. Note that this feature may apply to runs of more than two glyphs, and would not be used in monospaced fonts. Also note that this feature does not apply to text set vertically.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'kern'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STANDARD_LIGATURES
member.summary:
Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. This feature covers the ligatures which the designer/manufacturer judges should be used in normal conditions.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'liga'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_LINING_FIGURES
member.summary:
Changes selected figures from oldstyle to the default lining form. For example, a user may invoke this feature in order to get lining figures, which fit better with all-capital text. This feature overrides results of the Oldstyle Figures feature (onum).
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'lnum'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_LOCALIZED_FORMS
member.summary:
Enables localized forms of glyphs to be substituted for default forms. Many scripts used to write multiple languages over wide geographical areas have developed localized variant forms of specific letters, which are used by individual literary communities. For example, a number of letters in the Bulgarian and Serbian alphabets have forms distinct from their Russian counterparts and from each other. In some cases the localized form differs only subtly from the script 'norm', in others the forms are radically distinct.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'locl'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_MARK_POSITIONING
member.summary:
Positions mark glyphs with respect to base glyphs. For example, in Arabic script positioning the Hamza above the Yeh.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'mark'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_MATHEMATICAL_GREEK
member.summary:
Replaces standard typographic forms of Greek glyphs with corresponding forms commonly used in mathematical notation (which are a subset of the Greek alphabet).
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'mgrk'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_MARK_TO_MARK_POSITIONING
member.summary:
Positions marks with respect to other marks. Required in various non-Latin scripts like Arabic. For example, in Arabic, the ligaturised mark Ha with Hamza above it can also be obtained by positioning these marks relative to one another.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'mkmk'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_ALTERNATE_ANNOTATION_FORMS
member.summary:
Replaces default glyphs with various notational forms (such as glyphs placed in open or solid circles, squares, parentheses, diamonds or rounded boxes). In some cases an annotation form may already be present, but the user may want a different one.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'nalt'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_NLC_KANJI_FORMS
member.summary:
Used to access glyphs made from glyph shapes defined by the National Language Council (NLC) of Japan for a number of JIS characters in 2000.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'nlck'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_OLD_STYLE_FIGURES
member.summary:
Changes selected figures from the default lining style to oldstyle form. For example, a user may invoke this feature to get oldstyle figures, which fit better into the flow of normal upper- and lowercase text. This feature overrides results of the Lining Figures feature (lnum).
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'onum'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_ORDINALS
member.summary:
Replaces default alphabetic glyphs with the corresponding ordinal forms for use after figures. One exception to the follows-a-figure rule is the numero character (U+2116), which is actually a ligature substitution, but is best accessed through this feature.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ordn'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_PROPORTIONAL_ALTERNATE_WIDTH
member.summary:
Respaces glyphs designed to be set on full-em widths, fitting them onto individual (more or less proportional) horizontal widths. This differs from pwid in that it does not substitute new glyphs (GPOS, not GSUB feature). The user may prefer the monospaced form, or may simply want to ensure that the glyph is well-fit and not rotated in vertical setting (Latin forms designed for proportional spacing would be rotated).
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'palt'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_PETITE_CAPITALS
member.summary:
Turns lowercase characters into petite capitals. Forms related to petite capitals, such as specially designed figures, may be included. Some fonts contain an additional size of capital letters, shorter than the regular smallcaps and it is referred to as petite caps. Such forms are most likely to be found in designs with a small lowercase x-height, where they better harmonise with lowercase text than the taller smallcaps (for examples of petite caps, see the Emigre type families Mrs Eaves and Filosofia).
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'pcap'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_PROPORTIONAL_FIGURES
member.summary:
Replaces figure glyphs set on uniform (tabular) widths with corresponding glyphs set on glyph-specific (proportional) widths. Tabular widths will generally be the default, but this cannot be safely assumed. Of course this feature would not be present in monospaced designs.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'pnum'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_PROPORTIONAL_WIDTHS
member.summary:
Replaces glyphs set on uniform widths (typically full or half-em) with proportionally spaced glyphs. The proportional variants are often used for the Latin characters in CJKV fonts, but may also be used for Kana in Japanese fonts.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'pwid'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_QUARTER_WIDTHS
member.summary:
Replaces glyphs on other widths with glyphs set on widths of one quarter of an em (half an en). The characters involved are normally figures and some forms of punctuation.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'qwid'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_REQUIRED_LIGATURES
member.summary:
Replaces a sequence of glyphs with a single glyph which is preferred for typographic purposes. This feature covers those ligatures, which the script determines as required to be used in normal conditions. This feature is important for some scripts to ensure correct glyph formation.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'rlig'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_RUBY_NOTATION_FORMS
member.summary:
Identifies glyphs in the font which have been designed for "ruby", from the old typesetting term for four-point-sized type. Japanese typesetting often uses smaller kana glyphs, generally in superscripted form, to clarify the meaning of kanji which may be unfamiliar to the reader.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ruby'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_ALTERNATES
member.summary:
Replaces the default forms with the stylistic alternates. Many fonts contain alternate glyph designs for a purely esthetic effect; these don't always fit into a clear category like swash or historical. As in the case of swash glyphs, there may be more than one alternate form.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'salt'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_SCIENTIFIC_INFERIORS
member.summary:
Replaces lining or oldstyle figures with inferior figures (smaller glyphs which sit lower than the standard baseline, primarily for chemical or mathematical notation). May also replace lowercase characters with alphabetic inferiors.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'sinf'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_SMALL_CAPITALS
member.summary:
Turns lowercase characters into small capitals. This corresponds to the common SC font layout. It is generally used for display lines set in Large & small caps, such as titles. Forms related to small capitals, such as oldstyle figures, may be included.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'smcp'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_SIMPLIFIED_FORMS
member.summary:
Replaces 'traditional' Chinese or Japanese forms with the corresponding 'simplified' forms.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'smpl'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1
member.summary:
In addition to, or instead of, stylistic alternatives of individual glyphs (see 'salt' feature), some fonts may contain sets of stylistic variant glyphs corresponding to portions of the character set, such as multiple variants for lowercase letters in a Latin font. Glyphs in stylistic sets may be designed to harmonise visually, interract in particular ways, or otherwise work together. Examples of fonts including stylistic sets are Zapfino Linotype and Adobe's Poetica. Individual features numbered sequentially with the tag name convention 'ss01' 'ss02' 'ss03' . 'ss20' provide a mechanism for glyphs in these sets to be associated via GSUB lookup indexes to default forms and to each other, and for users to select from available stylistic sets
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss01'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_2
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss02'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_3
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss03'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_4

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_5

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_6

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_8

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_9

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_10

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_11
member.summary:

Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss11'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_12
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss12'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_13
member.summary:

Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss13'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_14
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_15
member.summary:

Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss15'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_16
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss16'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_17
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.
Equivalent OpenType tag: 'ss17'

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_18
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.

member.name: DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG::DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_19
member.summary:
See the description for DWRITE_FONT_FEATURE_TAG_STYLISTIC_SET_1.
